column2: To create a new task an object of TaskManager class is passed to the class constructor. The TaskManager in its turn takes care of a resource allocation using ResourceAssignmentCollection class.

column1: Create a new task which typically has a  start date and an end date. Tasks are activities that one or more persons resources are expected to complete in the specified time frame.
column2: The Task class provides a public method SetStart() which allows to specify starting date for the task. As input argument the method takes an object of GanttCalendar class.

column1: Create a new task which typically has a  start date and an end date. Tasks are activities that one or more persons resources are expected to complete in the specified time frame.
column2: The Task class provides a public method SetEnd() which allows to specify starting date for the task. As input argument the method takes an object of GanttCalendar class.

column1: Create a new task which typically has a  start date and an end date. Tasks are activities that one or more persons resources are expected to complete in the specified time frame.
column2: The Task class provides a public method SetDuration() which allows to specify the duration of the task. As input argument the method takes an object of TaskLength class

column1: Delete Tasks; Delete an existing task and all its associated information such as links to other tasks or knowledge on what resources are supposed to work on them.
column2: To delete a task from the Calendar the GanttProject class call delete method and supplied TaskId paramenter. The adjustment of allocated resources and links to other tasks takes place through interfacing with the following classes DefaultMutableTreeNode, GanttTreeTableNode, TaskNode, and AdjustTaskBoundsAlgorithm.

column1: Delete Tasks; Delete an existing task and all its associated information such as links to other tasks or knowledge on what resources are supposed to work on them.
column2: When deleting a task the GanttProject class calls GanttTreeTableNode and DefaultMutableTreeNode classes to identify the parent of the task being deleted.

column1: Delete Tasks; Delete an existing task and all its associated information such as links to other tasks or knowledge on what resources are supposed to work on them.
column2: When deleting a task the GanttProject class calls AdjustTaskBoundsAlgorithm and passes the parent of the deleted task as a parameter. The AdjustTaskBoundsAlgorithm takes care of handling and releasing resources associated with the deleted task.

column1: Maintain task properties;  Edit and update task properties including start and end date, name, or progress(% complete).
column2: GUI should able to provide ability to change task name.

column1: Maintain task properties;  Edit and update task properties including start and end date, name, or progress(% complete).
column2: GUI should able to provide ability to change start/end date of a task.

column1: Maintain task properties;  Edit and update task properties including start and end date, name, or progress(% complete).
column2: GUI should able to provide ability to set progress on a task.

column1: Add/Remove Tasks as Subtasks;A task can be made a subtask of another. For example, task 1.1 is a subtask of task 1.
column2: To add tasks as subtasks a method which indent the selected task nodes in GUI and change them to be subtasks is used. A manager of task hierarchy provides functions to update the relationship between tasks.

column1: Add/Remove Tasks as Subtasks;A task can be made a subtask of another. For example, task 1.1 is a subtask of task 1.
column2: The manager of task hierarchy provides a method to move a task node to a specific position.

column1: Add/Remove Tasks as Subtasks;A task can be made a subtask of another. For example, task 1.1 is a subtask of task 1.
column2: To remove tasks as subtasks GanttTree2 class calls a method which dedent selected task nodes in GUI so that they will not be subtasks of their original parents tasks. An object of a class is used to remove relationship between selected tasks and their original parents and add relationship between selected tasks and their new parents.

column1: Add/Remove Tasks as Subtasks;A task can be made a subtask of another. For example, task 1.1 is a subtask of task 1.
column2: To remove tasks as subtasks a method which dedent selected task nodes in GUI so that they will not be subtasks of their original parents tasks is used. The task tree model provides methods to remove relationship between selected tasks and their original parents and add relationship between selected tasks and their new parents.

column1: Handle Milestones; A milestone is a special task. Whereas a task typically has a timeframe specified (the time needed to complete the task), a milestone is typically an event. For example, the release date of a software is an event rather than a timeframe.
column2: Milestone is a task with no duration. It has only time point of occurrence.

column1: Handle Milestones; A milestone is a special task. Whereas a task typically has a timeframe specified (the time needed to complete the task), a milestone is typically an event. For example, the release date of a software is an event rather than a timeframe.
column2: User should be able to create milestones.

column1: Handle Milestones; A milestone is a special task. Whereas a task typically has a timeframe specified (the time needed to complete the task), a milestone is typically an event. For example, the release date of a software is an event rather than a timeframe.
column2: User interface should be able to provide an ability to specify whether a specific task in a milestone.

column1: Handle Milestones; A milestone is a special task. Whereas a task typically has a timeframe specified (the time needed to complete the task), a milestone is typically an event. For example, the release date of a software is an event rather than a timeframe.
column2: Milestone should be displayed visually differently from regular tasks.

column1: Create Resources (person);GanttProject supports Persons as resources. Persons have names and holidays or vacation days. Persons can be assigned to work on tasks.
column2: A GUI of task property provides interface and functions to add and remove human resource assignments by using an object of the resource assignments collection class.

column1: Create Resources (person);GanttProject supports Persons as resources. Persons have names and holidays or vacation days. Persons can be assigned to work on tasks.
column2: The human resource class contains name, phone, email, and holidays. The class provides functions to set and get these properties. A class is used to represent the holidays. There can be multiple holidays.

column1: Create Resources (person);GanttProject supports Persons as resources. Persons have names and holidays or vacation days. Persons can be assigned to work on tasks.
column2: The class for holidays provides functions to get the start date and the finish date. The class also provides a function to check if a special date is in holiday.

column1: Create Resources (person);GanttProject supports Persons as resources. Persons have names and holidays or vacation days. Persons can be assigned to work on tasks.
column2: A human resource assignment class is used to represent the relationship between one task and one human resource. The class provides functions to get the task and the human resource.

column1: Create Resources (person);GanttProject supports Persons as resources. Persons have names and holidays or vacation days. Persons can be assigned to work on tasks.
column2: A collection of resource assignments is used to manage the relationships between multiple human resources and a single task. It contains multiple objects of the human resource assignment class. The collection provides functions to add and remove human resource assignments.

column1: Create Resources (person);GanttProject supports Persons as resources. Persons have names and holidays or vacation days. Persons can be assigned to work on tasks.
column2: The class of task uses an object of the assignments collection class to manage its assignments.

column1: Delete Resources (person); Delete a person and all its associated information such as dependencies to all tasks the person is supposed to work on.
column2: GUI needs to provide ability to delete resources from a project.

column1: Delete Resources (person); Delete a person and all its associated information such as dependencies to all tasks the person is supposed to work on.
column2: An assignment of a resource to a task is captured as a relationship.

column1: Delete Resources (person); Delete a person and all its associated information such as dependencies to all tasks the person is supposed to work on.
column2: When a resource is removed, all the tasks where the resource is assigned need to be updated.

column1: Maintain Resource Properties;A resource has a range of properties, including name and holidays
column2: The human resource class contains name, phone, email, and holidays. The class provides functions to set and get these properties. A class is used to represent the holidays. There can be multiple holidays.

column1: Maintain Resource Properties;A resource has a range of properties, including name and holidays
column2: A GUI provides interface and functions to edit the properties of objects of the human resource class.

column1: Maintain Resource Properties;A resource has a range of properties, including name and holidays
column2: The class for holidays provides functions to get the start date and the finish date. The class also provides function to check if a special date is in holiday.

column1: Add/Remove Task links; Tasks can be linked with one another to indicate the sequence in which they have to be performed. For example, if there is a link from task 1 to task 2 then task 2 can only be started after task 1 is completed. The start date of task 2 must thus be after the end date of task 1.
column2: GUI needs to provide ability to link tasks in a project.

column1: Add/Remove Task links; Tasks can be linked with one another to indicate the sequence in which they have to be performed. For example, if there is a link from task 1 to task 2 then task 2 can only be started after task 1 is completed. The start date of task 2 must thus be after the end date of task 1.
column2: The fact of linking of one task to another should be captured as dependency between two tasks.

column1: Add/Remove Task links; Tasks can be linked with one another to indicate the sequence in which they have to be performed. For example, if there is a link from task 1 to task 2 then task 2 can only be started after task 1 is completed. The start date of task 2 must thus be after the end date of task 1.
column2: When a two or more tasks are link, there should be check conducted for potential collisions on the chart.

column1: Add/Remove Task links; Tasks can be linked with one another to indicate the sequence in which they have to be performed. For example, if there is a link from task 1 to task 2 then task 2 can only be started after task 1 is completed. The start date of task 2 must thus be after the end date of task 1.
column2: The start and end dates for the graph can be either flexible or rigid for the purpose of adjusting and fixing potential collisions.

column1: Add/Remove Resources to Tasks Dependencies;Dependencies between tasks and resources indicate the resources who are supposed to complete a task. Each task could be worked on by multiple persons and each person could work on multiple tasks. Dependencies may also be annotated to capture how many hours each person is supposed to work on a task on a daily basis.
column2: A class is used to represent the dependency between one task and one human resource. The dependency class provides functions to get the task and the human resource.

column1: Add/Remove Resources to Tasks Dependencies;Dependencies between tasks and resources indicate the resources who are supposed to complete a task. Each task could be worked on by multiple persons and each person could work on multiple tasks. Dependencies may also be annotated to capture how many hours each person is supposed to work on a task on a daily basis.
column2: A collection of resource assignments is used to manage the relationships between multiple human resources and a task. It contains multiple objects of the human resource assignment class. The collection provides functions to add and remove human resource assignments.

column1: Add/Remove Resources to Tasks Dependencies;Dependencies between tasks and resources indicate the resources who are supposed to complete a task. Each task could be worked on by multiple persons and each person could work on multiple tasks. Dependencies may also be annotated to capture how many hours each person is supposed to work on a task on a daily basis.
column2: The class of task uses an object of the assignments collection class to manage its assignments.

column1: Add/Remove Resources to Tasks Dependencies;Dependencies between tasks and resources indicate the resources who are supposed to complete a task. Each task could be worked on by multiple persons and each person could work on multiple tasks. Dependencies may also be annotated to capture how many hours each person is supposed to work on a task on a daily basis.
column2: The human resource class can have multiple objects of resource assignments which assigns this resource to tasks. The class provides function to get the list of these objects.

column1: Add/Remove Resources to Tasks Dependencies;Dependencies between tasks and resources indicate the resources who are supposed to complete a task. Each task could be worked on by multiple persons and each person could work on multiple tasks. Dependencies may also be annotated to capture how many hours each person is supposed to work on a task on a daily basis.
column2: A GUI class of task property provides interface and functions to add and remove human resource assignments.

column1: Add/Remove Resources to Tasks Dependencies;Dependencies between tasks and resources indicate the resources who are supposed to complete a task. Each task could be worked on by multiple persons and each person could work on multiple tasks. Dependencies may also be annotated to capture how many hours each person is supposed to work on a task on a daily basis.
column2: A GUI class uses an object of resource tree table model class to display the resource tree. The resource tree table model provides functions build subtrees based on dependencies.

column1: Add/Remove Resources to Tasks Dependencies;Dependencies between tasks and resources indicate the resources who are supposed to complete a task. Each task could be worked on by multiple persons and each person could work on multiple tasks. Dependencies may also be annotated to capture how many hours each person is supposed to work on a task on a daily basis.
column2: A GUI class of human resource load distribution uses objects of a load distribution class to capture the hours each person is supposed to work.

column1: Add/Remove Resources to Tasks Dependencies;Dependencies between tasks and resources indicate the resources who are supposed to complete a task. Each task could be worked on by multiple persons and each person could work on multiple tasks. Dependencies may also be annotated to capture how many hours each person is supposed to work on a task on a daily basis.
column2: The load distribution class provides functions to calculate the distribution based on tasks and human resources. The functions uses the task manager.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times manually with user changes; Change the start or end date either by editing its properties or by dragging-and-dropping the bar in the GUI.
column2: GUI needs to provide ability to change length of a task.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times manually with user changes; Change the start or end date either by editing its properties or by dragging-and-dropping the bar in the GUI.
column2: Using GUI user should be able to change the length of a task by dragging-and-dropping the bar on the GUI.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times manually with user changes; Change the start or end date either by editing its properties or by dragging-and-dropping the bar in the GUI.
column2: Using GUI user should be able to change the length of a task via date picker control.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes;The start or end date should be changed automatically if links among tasks are changed
column2: A dependency class contains a dependant task and a dependee task. It provides functions to get the dependant task and the dependee task. The dependency class also contains constraint to show the constraint of the dependency.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes;The start or end date should be changed automatically if links among tasks are changed
column2: A class is used to represent the constraint that the start date of the dependee task should not be earlier than the end date of the dependent task.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes;The start or end date should be changed automatically if links among tasks are changed
column2: A collection of dependency class is used to manage dependencies. It contains objects of dependency classes and provides functions to create, delete, and get dependencies.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes;The start or end date should be changed automatically if links among tasks are changed
column2: A GUI class of task property provides interface and functions to add and remove dependencies by using an object of the dependency collection.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes;The start or end date should be changed automatically if links among tasks are changed
column2: A GUI class of graphic area provides function to draw dependency. The function uses an object of task manager to add dependencies.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes;The start or end date should be changed automatically if links among tasks are changed
column2: The task manager class uses an object of dependency collection class to manage dependencies.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes;The start or end date should be changed automatically if links among tasks are changed
column2: An object of the recalculating task schedule algorithm class is used to change the start or end date based on dependency changes. The algorithm class provides functions to fulfill the constraints and to modify the start or end date of the tasks.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes; The start or end date should be changed automatically if one of its subtasks changes.
column2: Application needs to keep track of task's begin and end times.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes; The start or end date should be changed automatically if one of its subtasks changes.
column2: Application needs to keep track of subtasks in a task.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes; The start or end date should be changed automatically if one of its subtasks changes.
column2: Every time Start/End time for a subtask changes, the start/end time for the parent task need to change accordingly.

column1: Change Task Begin/End Times automatically with dependency changes; The start or end date should be changed automatically if one of its subtasks changes.
column2: Every time Start/End time for a task changes, the start/end time of one or more its subtasks need to change as well.

column1: Prevent Circular Dependencies;Links among tasks may not be circular in that task 1 cannot depend on task 2 if task 2 already depends on task 1.
column2: A GUI class of graphic area provides a function to draw dependency. The function uses an object of the task manager to add dependencies.1

column1: Prevent Circular Dependencies;Links among tasks may not be circular in that task 1 cannot depend on task 2 if task 2 already depends on task 1.
column2: The task manager class uses an object of dependency collection class to manage dependencies.

column1: Prevent Circular Dependencies;Links among tasks may not be circular in that task 1 cannot depend on task 2 if task 2 already depends on task 1.
column2: The class of dependency collection provides a function to check if the new dependency will cause a loop each time a object of dependency class is created. The function returns an exception if there is a loop.

column1: Show Critical Path; The critical path indicates which tasks will cause project delays if they are delayed.
column2: GUI needs to provide ability to display critical path and make the changes affecting critical path updated.

column1: Show Critical Path; The critical path indicates which tasks will cause project delays if they are delayed.
column2: The system should be able to evaluate critical path in a project.

column1: Add/Remove Holidays and Vacation Days;Holidays and vacation days are properties of persons (resources). changing this information also changes the availability of a person on certain days.
column2: The human resource class contains the variable holidays. The class provides functions to change and to get holidays. There can be multiple holidays.

column1: Add/Remove Holidays and Vacation Days;Holidays and vacation days are properties of persons (resources). changing this information also changes the availability of a person on certain days.
column2: There is a class to represent holiday. The holiday class provides functions to set the begin date and the end date of the holiday, to check if a date is in the holiday, and to get the duration of the holiday.

column1: Add/Remove Holidays and Vacation Days;Holidays and vacation days are properties of persons (resources). changing this information also changes the availability of a person on certain days.
column2: The human resource class provides a function to change the availability of the person based on holidays.

column1: Show Resource Utilization (underused or overused person);Tasks may be assigned to persons and it should be indicated if a person receives more tasks than he/she is able to handle (e.g., the person hours per  task for all tasks exceeds the allowed 8 hours a day) or if the person is not available due to holidays or vacation days. it should also be indicated if the person is under-utilized in that he/she is working less than the 8 hours a day.
column2: GUI needs to provide ability to assign task to persons.

column1: Show Resource Utilization (underused or overused person);Tasks may be assigned to persons and it should be indicated if a person receives more tasks than he/she is able to handle (e.g., the person hours per  task for all tasks exceeds the allowed 8 hours a day) or if the person is not available due to holidays or vacation days. it should also be indicated if the person is under-utilized in that he/she is working less than the 8 hours a day.
column2: GUI needs to provide ability to assign persons to tasks.

column1: Show Resource Utilization (underused or overused person);Tasks may be assigned to persons and it should be indicated if a person receives more tasks than he/she is able to handle (e.g., the person hours per  task for all tasks exceeds the allowed 8 hours a day) or if the person is not available due to holidays or vacation days. it should also be indicated if the person is under-utilized in that he/she is working less than the 8 hours a day.
column2: GUI needs to provide ability to show utilization of a person.

column1: Show Resource Utilization (underused or overused person);Tasks may be assigned to persons and it should be indicated if a person receives more tasks than he/she is able to handle (e.g., the person hours per  task for all tasks exceeds the allowed 8 hours a day) or if the person is not available due to holidays or vacation days. it should also be indicated if the person is under-utilized in that he/she is working less than the 8 hours a day.
column2: GUI needs to provide ability to show is a person is  underutilized and overbooked.

column1: The core functionality of WARC Tools, specifically the WARC writer/reader, shall be implemented as a comprehensive, standalone, general purpose software library - libwarc.
column2: A set of command line tools and an API incorporating libwarc shall enable the collection of online documents, such as html and embedded files, etc., and write them to valid WARC- records.

column1: WARC v0.17 shall be the baseline version of the WARC standard used in this project.
column2: Libwarc shall be implemented to WARC v0.17.

column1: WARC Tools shall be highly portable, running on a range of Linux/Unix platforms and XP as a minimum, together with man pages, build and installation guides, developer guides, etc.
column2: Libwarc shall be developed on GNU/Linux, Fedora 7

column2: Libwarc shall be shipped with a manual and build scripts

column1: Utility and application level functionality of WARC Tools shall be made available to end users as command line tools, extensions to existing tools, and simple web applications for accessing WARC content.
column2: A command line tool shall be implemented utilising libwarc to check the consistency of WARC-records and their conformance to the WARC ISO standard.

column2: A command line tool "arc2warc" incorporating libwarc shall be able to migrate data in ARC-records to WARC-record format.

column1: Communication and support shall be provided to the open source community. This support must be provided for at least term of the project.

column1: The WARC Tools shall be implemented as a C library
column2: Libwarc shall be implemented in C and shall conform to ANSI-C standard C99 revision.

column1: The WARC Tools shall be implemented as a C library
column2: To ensure code portability on older computer architectures, Libwarc shall be compatible with any compiler conforming to the ANSI-C standard C89 revision.

column1: Library functionality shall have APIs and dynamic language bindings to be made available as software libraries for developers.
column2: Python scripts shall be implemented incorporating libwarc, and making all of the functionality of libwarc and API available in Python.

column1: Library functionality shall have APIs and dynamic language bindings to be made available as software libraries for developers.
column2: Libwarc shall provide interfaces to SWIG wrappers to allow dynamic language bindings (Python, Ruby, Perl, Lua ...)

column1: Library functionality shall have APIs and dynamic language bindings to be made available as software libraries for developers.
column2: A Python interface to libwarc shall be implemented using the SWIG wrapper

column1: Library functionality shall have APIs and dynamic language bindings to be made available as software libraries for developers.
column2: Libwarc and the bindings to its functionality shall enable the use of libwarc's iterators described in SRS 16-20 to be used within various dynamic languages and in Java v1.4 and earlier, using metaphors and paradigms familiar to those languages.

column1: Web server plug-ins shall conform to the Apache 'mod' API and shall operate correctly with both Apache and Lighttp servers and shall be compatible with appropriate web sever programming standards, such as WSGI in Python and the Servlet API in Java.
column2: Libwarc shall be incorporated within an Apache module to enable all actions specified in SRS 34-36 to be executed within Apache.

column1: Web server plug-ins shall conform to the Apache 'mod' API and shall operate correctly with both Apache and Lighttp servers and shall be compatible with appropriate web sever programming standards, such as WSGI in Python and the Servlet API in Java.
column2: Libwarc shall be incorporated within a Lighttp module to enable all actions specified in SRS 34-36 to be executed within lighttp.

column1: The deliverables shall be made available in source code, named as "libwarc-version.tar.gz", where version is the version of the library. A number of binary distributions may be made, including RPM, DEB and EXE.
column2: Libwarc source code shall be released in the following archives: "libwarc-version.tar.gz", "libwarc-version.tar.bz2", "libwarc-version.zip" together with their corresponding digests. Developers may then adapt the build configuration files for best performance on their target machines.

column1: The deliverables shall be made available in source code, named as "libwarc-version.tar.gz", where version is the version of the library. A number of binary distributions may be made, including RPM, DEB and EXE.
column2: Libwarc binary modules, ready to use binary commands and libraries (both static and shared), compiled with generic optimisation flags, shall be released also

column2: Libwarc shall be made available as a binary for at least GNU/Linux, FreeBSD, Mac OS X and Windows XP.

column2: Libwarc shall compile and run under Solaris, AIX, MingW or other Unix compliant system and may compile and run under Windows XP.

column1: The final WARC API shall be coded in C with minimum dependencies or external libraries (e.g. GZIP). It must not include any assembly code.
column2: To ensure code portability on older computer architectures, Libwarc shall be compatible with any compiler conforming to the ANSI-C standard C89 revision.

column1: The final WARC API shall be coded in C with minimum dependencies or external libraries (e.g. GZIP). It must not include any assembly code.
column2: Only essential external libraries shall be used in libwarc, such as Gzip compression and wide characters encoding libraries.

column1: The final WARC API shall be coded in C with minimum dependencies or external libraries (e.g. GZIP). It must not include any assembly code.
column2: Assembly code and specific system features shall not be used in libwarc to ensure resulting code is widely portable across multiple target architectures

column1: The C library will be developed in such a way as to allow it to be used with the Simplified Wrapper and Interface Generator, or SWIG, (www.swig.org) in order to wrap the C code and allow it to be called natively in a wide variety of languages.
column2: Libwarc shall provide interfaces to SWIG wrappers to allow dynamic language bindings (Python, Ruby, Perl, Lua ...)

column1: An interface implementation may be made for Python to allow the library to be used natively by Python programmers requiring no knowledge of the internal implementation of libwarc or C.
column2: Python scripts shall be implemented incorporating libwarc, and making all of the functionality of libwarc and API available in Python.

column1: An interface implementation may be made for Python to allow the library to be used natively by Python programmers requiring no knowledge of the internal implementation of libwarc or C.
column2: Libwarc shall provide interfaces to SWIG wrappers to allow dynamic language bindings (Python, Ruby, Perl, Lua ...)

column1: An interface implementation may be made for Python to allow the library to be used natively by Python programmers requiring no knowledge of the internal implementation of libwarc or C.
column2: A Python interface to libwarc shall be implemented using the SWIG wrapper

column1: An interface implementation shall be made for Java to allow the library to be used natively by Java programmers requiring no knowledge of the internal implementation of libwarc or C.
column2: A Java interface to libwarc shall be implemented using the SWIG wrapper and/or JNI

column1: An interface implementation shall be made for Java to allow the library to be used natively by Java programmers requiring no knowledge of the internal implementation of libwarc or C.
column2: An independent Java implementation of libwarc may be implemented subject to review of deliverables satisfying SRS 61

column1: An interface implementation shall be made for Java to allow the library to be used natively by Java programmers requiring no knowledge of the internal implementation of libwarc or C.
column2: Libwarc and the bindings to its functionality shall enable the use of libwarc's iterators described in SRS 16-20 to be used within various dynamic languages and in Java v1.4 and earlier, using metaphors and paradigms familiar to those languages.

column1: An interface implementation shall be made for Java to allow the library to be used natively by Java programmers requiring no knowledge of the internal implementation of libwarc or C.
column2: Libwarc and the bindings to its functionality shall enable the use of libwarc's iterators described in SRS 16-20 to be used within Java v1.5 and and later, using Java's new container iterators, such as "for" and "foreach".

column1: The functionality of the library shall be exposed in such a way as to fit the metaphors and paradigms of the specific implementation languages (C, Java, Python).
column2: Python scripts shall be implemented incorporating libwarc, and making all of the functionality of libwarc and API available in Python.

column2: Libwarc shall provide interfaces to SWIG wrappers to allow dynamic language bindings (Python, Ruby, Perl, Lua ...)

column2: A Python interface to libwarc shall be implemented using the SWIG wrapper

column1: Any software tool or application based on libwarc shall require just a single header file.
column2: There shall be a single entry point to libwarc, called "warc.h".

column1: Any software tool or application based on libwarc shall require just a single header file.
column2: The "libwarc" headers shall be structured in a hierarchical manner. The universal header "warc.h" will include all of them.

column1: Any software tool or application based on libwarc shall require just a single header file.
column2: It shall be possible for developers to access, modify and manipulate of all aspects of the WARC file format by including this single header file.

column1: Any software tool or application based on libwarc shall require just a single header file.
column2: The universal header "warc.h" shall ensure compatibility between all versions of libwarc.

column1: Any software tool or application based on libwarc shall require just a single header file.
column2: The universal header "warc.h" shall ensure that deprecated function calls and changes to the library are notified at compile time.

column1: Any software tool or application based on libwarc shall require just a single header file.
column2: The universal header "warc.h" shall provide normalised interfaces to enable developers to create valid and compliant WARC-records, based on the definition in the "ISO TC 46/SC 4 N 595" standards document. The interfaces shall be made available to create WARC records of the following types:- "warinfo"- "response"- "request"- "metadata"- "revisit"- "conversion"- "continuation"- "resource"

column1: The libwarc interfaces shall fully encapsulate and internal functionality, isolating by abstraction any tool or application based on libwarc from changes in the internal implementation.
column2: The universal header "warc.h" shall ensure compatibility between all versions of libwarc.

column1: The libwarc interfaces shall fully encapsulate and internal functionality, isolating by abstraction any tool or application based on libwarc from changes in the internal implementation.
column2: The universal header "warc.h" shall ensure that deprecated function calls and changes to the library are notified at compile time.

column1: The libwarc interfaces shall fully encapsulate and internal functionality, isolating by abstraction any tool or application based on libwarc from changes in the internal implementation.
column2: The interfaces in libwarc shall ensure that any changes to the library, will not affect any tool or application based on libwarc.

column1: The libwarc interfaces shall fully encapsulate and internal functionality, isolating by abstraction any tool or application based on libwarc from changes in the internal implementation.
column2: Libwarc shall provide an API describing (1) the set of data, and (2) the set of operations that can be performed on the data. The data types shall be abstract (abstract data types - ADT), to ensure independence of concrete implementations.

column1: The libwarc interfaces shall fully encapsulate and internal functionality, isolating by abstraction any tool or application based on libwarc from changes in the internal implementation.
column2: Libwarc shall encapsulate and handle all memory management when processing WARCrecords.

column1: The libwarc interfaces shall fully encapsulate and internal functionality, isolating by abstraction any tool or application based on libwarc from changes in the internal implementation.
column2: Major revisions to the WARC ISO standard may lead to revisions of libwarc, but these revisions should be isolated and not affect any tools developed incorporating libwarc

column1: Libwarc shall provide a range of functions through a universal interface for creating each type of valid WARC-record, thus ensuring the resulting WARC files conform to the prevailing WARC standard
column2: The universal header "warc.h" shall provide normalised interfaces to enable developers to create valid and compliant WARC-records, based on the definition in the "ISO TC 46/SC 4 N 595" standards document. The interfaces shall be made available to create WARC records of the following types:- "warinfo"- "response"- "request"- "metadata"- "revisit"- "conversion"- "continuation"- "resource"

column1: For each type of WARC-record, a set of functions shall be made available to create/modify the records properties.
column2: Each WARC-record shall be accessible via a peer C class of the same name.

column1: For each type of WARC-record, a set of functions shall be made available to create/modify the records properties.
column2: The attributes of each WARC-record, as per the ISO standard specification, shall have a corresponding attribute in its peer C class.

column1: For each type of WARC-record, a set of functions shall be made available to create/modify the records properties.
column2: Each peer class shall expose a set a class functions to read, write, and update attributes for the corresponding WARC-record.

column1: Libwarc shall provide a range of functions through a universal interface for reading a range of valid WARC-records
column2: Libwarc shall provide an API describing (1) the set of data, and (2) the set of operations that can be performed on the data. The data types shall be abstract (abstract data types - ADT), to ensure independence of concrete implementations.

column1: Libwarc shall provide a range of functions through a universal interface for reading a range of valid WARC-records
column2: Any operations on WARC-records shall be possible using functions accepting the abstract handle as an argument.

column1: Libwarc shall provide a stable Application Programme Interface (API) to handle WARCrecords as abstract objects (ADT)
column2: Libwarc shall provide an API describing (1) the set of data, and (2) the set of operations that can be performed on the data. The data types shall be abstract (abstract data types - ADT), to ensure independence of concrete implementations.

column1: Libwarc shall provide a stable Application Programme Interface (API) to handle WARCrecords as abstract objects (ADT)
column2: It shall be possible to create a WARC-record using a constructor, which will returns an abstract handle to data representing the WARC-record.

column1: Libwarc shall provide a stable Application Programme Interface (API) to handle WARCrecords as abstract objects (ADT)
column2: Any operations on WARC-records shall be possible using functions accepting the abstract handle as an argument.

column1: Libwarc shall provide ARC-record reader functionality Libwarc reader will thereby make read operations as simple as possible.
column2: SRS 15 -Libwarc shall include ADT objects to handle read operations on ARC-records

column1: Libwarc shall provide a default iterator as a built-in function
column2: Libwarc shall provide a generic iterator, to enable the developer to iterate over all WARCrecords and create an abstract WARC-document as a simple container

column1: Libwarc shall provide a records iterator to handle WARC-type records
column2: Libwarc shall provide a generic iterator, to enable the developer to iterate over all WARCrecords and create an abstract WARC-document as a simple container

column1: Libwarc shall provide a records iterator to handle WARC-type records
column2: Libwarc shall provide a WARC-record-type iterator

column1: Libwarc shall provide a MIMES iterator to handle MIME-types payloads
column2: Libwarc shall provide a WARC-record MIME-type iterator

column1: Iterators can use exact pattern search or regex expressions
column2: Libwarc's generic iterators may be customised for different purposes via callback handlers (i.e. hooks)

column1: Libwarc shall provide an abstract interface for iterators, to enable custom iterators
column2: Libwarc's generic iterators may be customised for different purposes via callback handlers (i.e. hooks)

column1: Libwarc shall enable combinations of iterators to be used, i.e. composite iterators
column2: Libwarc's iterators may be combined into composite iterators to enable the developer to more than one search field

column1: Libwarc shall be memory safe and manage dynamic memory internally
column2: Libwarc shall encapsulate and handle all memory management when processing WARCrecords.

column1: Libwarc shall be memory safe and manage dynamic memory internally
column2: Developers using libwarc shall not be required to allocate/release memory directly, instead the developer shall use libwarc's object constructor and destructor functions.

column1: Libwarc shall be memory safe and manage dynamic memory internally
column2: Libwarc shall use dynamic heap memory for its internal usage.

column1: Libwarc shall be memory safe and manage dynamic memory internally
column2: Libwarc shall allocate minimum memory heap to store WARC-record metadata.

column1: Libwarc shall be memory safe and manage dynamic memory internally
column2: The payload (or the WARC-record document itself) are stored on disk, to avoid using memory heap, even for small objects.

column1: Libwarc shall be memory safe and manage dynamic memory internally
column2: Libwarc shall not use file to memory mapping technology, instead libwarc will explicitly allocate memory as needed.

column1: Libwarc shall use disk-based working memory
column2: The payload (or the WARC-record document itself) are stored on disk, to avoid using memory heap, even for small objects.

column1: Dynamic memory management shall be hidden inside libwarc
column2: Libwarc shall encapsulate and handle all memory management when processing WARCrecords.

column1: Dynamic memory management shall be hidden inside libwarc
column2: Developers using libwarc shall not be required to allocate/release memory directly, instead the developer shall use libwarc's object constructor and destructor functions.

column1: Dynamic memory management shall be hidden inside libwarc
column2: Libwarc shall use dynamic heap memory for its internal usage.

column1: Dynamic memory management shall be hidden inside libwarc
column2: Libwarc shall allocate minimum memory heap to store WARC-record metadata.

column1: Dynamic memory management shall be hidden inside libwarc
column2: The payload (or the WARC-record document itself) are stored on disk, to avoid using memory heap, even for small objects.

column1: Dynamic memory management shall be hidden inside libwarc
column2: Libwarc shall not use file to memory mapping technology, instead libwarc will explicitly allocate memory as needed.

column1: Libwarc shall use gzip as the default compression format
column2: Libwarc shall support non-compressed WARC-records and compressed WARC-records and files

column1: Libwarc shall use gzip as the default compression format
column2: The default compression format shall be Gzip

column1: Libwarc shall provide a plug-in interface to enable use of alternative compression libraries, such as "gzip2", "7zip", etc.
column2: Libwarc shall support multiple compression schemas, loading a specific compressor at runtime as an external shared library.

column1: Libwarc shall provide a plug-in interface to enable use of alternative compression libraries, such as "gzip2", "7zip", etc.
column2: It shall not be possible to use more than one compression schema (including noncompression) within a single WARC file. (i.e. it is not possible to mix compression schemes within a single WARC file).

column1: WARC files shall be validated using a command line tool, "w-validator", which will enable validation or rejection of WARC files.
column2: A command line tool shall be implemented utilising libwarc to check the consistency of WARC-records and their conformance to the WARC ISO standard.

column1: WARC files shall be validated using a command line tool, "w-validator", which will enable validation or rejection of WARC files.
column2: The command line tool shall notify the user of any WARC-record's anomalies, missing required fields or incompatible fields types.

column1: WARC Browser shall provide an API that allows browsing of WARC files and associated CDX files via an HTTP server
column2: It shall be possible to perform read operations (read from offset, filters, etc.) on WARCrecords from a remote location via http.

column1: WARC Browser shall provide an API that allows browsing of WARC files and associated CDX files via an HTTP server
column2: WARC browser shall not support CDX files because the CDX file format is not a standard at this time and is outside of scope.

column1: WARC Browser shall support a rewriting interface
column2: WARC Browser shall support a client-side rewriting interface by using javascript code to rewrite links being delivered alongside archived content. This is based on the principles implemented in the Wayback Machine.

column1: WARC Browser shall support a proxy-style interface
column2: SRS 38 -A web proxy interface shall be implemented that allows the user to set their web browser proxy to the one provided by the interface and thereby ensure all content is delivered from the archive and not from the live web.

column1: An Apache and Lighttp plug-in shall provide access to the libwarc API and WARC Browser over http
column2: Libwarc shall be incorporated within an Apache module to enable all actions specified in SRS 34-36 to be executed within Apache.

column1: An Apache and Lighttp plug-in shall provide access to the libwarc API and WARC Browser over http
column2: Libwarc shall be incorporated within a Lighttp module to enable all actions specified in SRS 34-36 to be executed within lighttp.

column1: It shall be possible to convert ARC files to WARC files using a command-line tool called "arc2warc"
column2: A command line tool "arc2warc" incorporating libwarc shall be able to migrate data in ARC-records to WARC-record format.

column1: It shall be possible to convert ARC files to WARC files using a command-line tool called "arc2warc"
column2: The default operation of "arc2warc" shall carry out a one-to-one mapping of record fields, by converting each ARC-record to a corresponding "response" WARC-record and "metadata" WARCrecord, which shall include information about the conversion process.

column1: It shall be possible to convert ARC files to WARC files using a command-line tool called "arc2warc"
column2: "arc2warc" shall have make a default operation in cases where an ARC-record has no corresponding field in the WARC-record.

column1: ARC to WARC conversions made by arc2warc shall be carried out according to a specification in a configuration file
column2: It shall be possible to specify non-default operations of "arc2warc" using a named configuration file, which will describe the desired ARC-record to WARC-record conversion.

column1: It shall be possible to collect HTTrack data from the directories output by HTTrack and write the data to WARC files
column2: A set of command line tools incorporating libwarc shall perform migration of "HTTrack" archives to WARC-records.

column1: It shall be possible to collect HTTrack data from the directories output by HTTrack and write the data to WARC files
column2: The HTTrack archive file format and link strategy may vary from version to version of HTTrack, therefore it shall be possible to adapt the migration scripts to deal with these changes.

column1: It shall be possible to walk a wget mirror and write the data to WARC files
column2: A set of command line tools incorporating libwarc shall perform migration of "wget" archives to WARC-records.

column1: It shall be possible to walk a curl directory and write the data to WARC files
column2: A set of command line tools incorporating libwarc shall perform migration of "curl" archives to WARC-records.

column1: It shall be possible to collect arbitrary web content, such as html files, images etc. (for example from a web server document root directory), and write the data to WARC files
column2: A set of command line tools and an API incorporating libwarc shall enable the collection of online documents, such as html and embedded files, etc., and write them to valid WARC- records.

column1: A Python script shall be made available to enable rapid development of WARC based solutions
column2: Python scripts shall be implemented incorporating libwarc, and making all of the functionality of libwarc and API available in Python.

column1: WARC extensions shall be released as a patch to each of the commands "curl", "wget", and "httrack" projects
column2: Extensions to "HTTrack", "wget" and "curl" incorporating libwarc shall be provided as patches to recent and specific versions of each tool, to enable users of the tool to access functionality of libwarc

column1: WARC extensions help content will be provided each of the commands "curl", "wget", and "httrack"
column2: Helper documentation for libwarc functionality shall be made available within the "HTTrack", "wget" and "curl" commands.

column1: It shall be possible to identify WARC files using the unix "file" command
column2: A magic number for WARC shall be created and incorporated in the "file" mime-type database, enabling the simple identification of WARC files via the Unix "file" command

column1: It shall be possible to identify and validate WARC files using "Jhove"
column2: The WARC validator tool specified in SRS 31-32 shall be extended to optionally make use of the Jhove command line API to identify and validate WARC files, i.e. given a specific WARC file, this command shall be able to identify the file as a WARC file, validate the level of compliance with a given standard in terms of well-formedness and validity, and finally to characterise the file by extracting and displaying significant properties contained in the file.

column1: It shall be possible to identify and validate WARC files using "Jhove"
column2: WarcMdoule and WarcHandler plugin modules shall be implemented for Jhove Plugin layer to enable identification and validation of WARC files.

column1: A Jhove plugin module and an output handler shall be made available for WARC files
column2: WarcMdoule and WarcHandler plugin modules shall be implemented for Jhove Plugin layer to enable identification and validation of WARC files.

column1: WARC files in various test-states shall be provided that test the Jhove deliverables
column2: WARC files in various test-states shall be provided that test the Jhove deliverables

column1: The C library shall be implemented to be compatible with the Simplified Wrapper and Interface Generator (SWIG, http://www.swig.org) - a wrapper for libwarc C code to allow it to be called natively in a wide variety of languages.
column2: Libwarc shall provide interfaces to SWIG wrappers to allow dynamic language bindings (Python, Ruby, Perl, Lua ...)

column1: A Python interface shall be implemented
column2: Python scripts shall be implemented incorporating libwarc, and making all of the functionality of libwarc and API available in Python.

column1: A Python interface shall be implemented
column2: A Python interface to libwarc shall be implemented using the SWIG wrapper

column1: A Java interface shall be implemented
column2: A Java interface to libwarc shall be implemented using the SWIG wrapper and/or JNI

column1: An independent Java implementation of libwarc may be implemented
column2: An independent Java implementation of libwarc may be implemented subject to review of deliverables satisfying SRS 61

column1: The functionality of the library shall be exposed in such a way as to fit the metaphors and paradigms of the implementation language
column2: Libwarc and the bindings to its functionality shall enable the use of libwarc's iterators described in SRS 16-20 to be used within various dynamic languages and in Java v1.4 and earlier, using metaphors and paradigms familiar to those languages.

column1: The functionality of the library shall be exposed in such a way as to fit the metaphors and paradigms of the implementation language
column2: Libwarc and the bindings to its functionality shall enable the use of libwarc's iterators described in SRS 16-20 to be used within Java v1.5 and and later, using Java's new container iterators, such as "for" and "foreach".

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Drug Reservoir The drug reservoir holds liquid drug until infused
column2: drug reservoir. The drug reservoir holds liquid pain-killer supplied by the hospital pharmacy and loaded into the PCA pump by the clinician

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Drug Reservoir The drug reservoir holds liquid drug until infused
column2: reservoir contents. The drug reservoir shall measure its contents

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Drug Reservoir The drug reservoir holds liquid drug until infused
column2: reservoir tolerance. The measured drug volume shall be within Vrt = 1 ml of the actual drug volume

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Drug Reservoir The drug reservoir holds liquid drug until infused
column2: low-reservoir warning. If the drug volume in the reservoir measures less than Vlra = 1 ml and an infusion is in progress a low-reservoir warning shall be issued

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Drug Reservoir The drug reservoir holds liquid drug until infused
column2: empty-reservoir alarm. If the drug volume in the reservoir measures less than Vers =0.5 ml and an infusion is in progress an empty-reservoir alarm shall be issued stopping the pump

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Drug Reservoir The drug reservoir holds liquid drug until infused
column2: tamper-resistant door. Because the drugs used for analgesia are often narcotic requiring Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) tracking if used in the United States the drug reservoir and means to change prescriptions during infusion must be inhibited with a locked tamper-resistant door

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Drug Reservoir The drug reservoir holds liquid drug until infused
column2: pump case. The PCA pump case must be at least difficult to breech as its tamper-resistant door. Breaking the case shall not be easier to access the drug reservoir than breeching the door

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Drug Reservoir The drug reservoir holds liquid drug until infused
column2: electronic tamper detection mechanisms. The PCA pump shall include electronic tamper detection mechanisms and shall record detected tampering attempts in the Fault Log and Event Log as well as issuing an authenticated ICE message

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Drug Reservoir The drug reservoir holds liquid drug until infused
column2: open door alarm. A open door alarm shall be triggered when the reservoir door is opened while the pump is not stopped

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Pump The pump moves fluid at specified rate  primes itself  announces if priming fails  indicates when it's too hot  and halts pumping when commanded
column2: basal infusion flow range. The pump shall be able to deliver basal infusion at flows throughout the basal infusion flow range of Fbasal min = 1 to Fbasal max = 10 ml/hr

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Pump The pump moves fluid at specified rate  primes itself  announces if priming fails  indicates when it's too hot  and halts pumping when commanded
column2: basal infusion flow tolerance. The pump shall deliver basal infusion at the prescribed basal rate within a basal infusion flow tolerance of Fbasal tol = 0.5 ml/hr of the prescribed basal rate

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Pump The pump moves fluid at specified rate  primes itself  announces if priming fails  indicates when it's too hot  and halts pumping when commanded
column2: pump drug. The mechanical pump shall pump drug at precribed flow rates for basal bolus and KVO infusion when commanded

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Pump The pump moves fluid at specified rate  primes itself  announces if priming fails  indicates when it's too hot  and halts pumping when commanded
column2: halt pumping. The mechanical pump shall halt pumping when commanded or caused in response to an alarm condition (at end of pump stoke?)

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Pump The pump moves fluid at specified rate  primes itself  announces if priming fails  indicates when it's too hot  and halts pumping when commanded
column2: pump overheated alarm. If the pump gets overheated to more than Tpoh = 55 C the pump shall issue a pump overloaded alarm

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Pump The pump moves fluid at specified rate  primes itself  announces if priming fails  indicates when it's too hot  and halts pumping when commanded
column2: complete pump stroke. When the stop button is pressed the current pump stroke shall be completed prior to stopping the pump

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Pump The pump moves fluid at specified rate  primes itself  announces if priming fails  indicates when it's too hot  and halts pumping when commanded
column2: continuous reverse delivery. During normal use and/or single fault condition of the equipment continuous reverse delivery shall not be possible (from IEC 601-2-24)

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Pump The pump moves fluid at specified rate  primes itself  announces if priming fails  indicates when it's too hot  and halts pumping when commanded
column2: occlusion alarm. When an occlusion alarm occurs the pump shall be stopped immediately without completing the current pump stroke

column1: Fluid Subsystem: Pump The pump moves fluid at specified rate  primes itself  announces if priming fails  indicates when it's too hot  and halts pumping when commanded
column2: reverse flow. The mechanical pump shall not allow reverse flow from the patient into the pump

column1: Functional Safety Architecture The functional safety architecture separates operation from error/fault detection  with a few exceptions. This allows safety requirements to be more easily achieved and verified. Components comprising the functional safety architecture are: Upstream Monitor Downstream Monitor Pump Fault Manager Alarm Thread  Error Detector Fault Logger  Failure LED  Power Control
column2: safety architecture. The PCA pump shall implement a safety architecture that separates normal operation from fault detection and response

column1: Operation Subsystem: Control Panel The control panel combines a touch panel with a speaker by which a clinician can enter and confirm configuration and see and hear alarms and warnings. is used by an authorized clinician to start and stop infusion displays the prescription read from the drug container by the scanner for confirmation or rejection. displays the PCA pump's status. allows request of a bolus by a clinician. allows entry of the clinician requested bolus duration displays alarm and warning indications sounds alerts for alarm and warning indications allows alarm inactivation displays if and how alarms are currently inactivated
column2: issue alarms and warnings. The PCA pump shall issue alarms and warnings that require clinician attention

column1: Operation Subsystem: Control Panel The control panel combines a touch panel with a speaker by which a clinician can enter and confirm configuration and see and hear alarms and warnings. is used by an authorized clinician to start and stop infusion displays the prescription read from the drug container by the scanner for confirmation or rejection. displays the PCA pump's status. allows request of a bolus by a clinician. allows entry of the clinician requested bolus duration displays alarm and warning indications sounds alerts for alarm and warning indications allows alarm inactivation displays if and how alarms are currently inactivated
column2: visual alarm signal. If a visual indicator is necessary for the clinicaian to identify the equipment or part of the equipment that requires clinician response or awareness at least one visual alarm signal shall be provided that 1. indicated the priority of the highest priority alarm condition

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: basal flow rate. The basal flow rate Fbasal is prescribed by a physician and entered into the PCA pump by scanning the prescription from the drug container label as it is loaded into the reservoir

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: minimum KVO flow rate. The pump shall maintain a minimum KVO flow rate of FKVO = 1/ml at all times during infusion even during alarms unless the alarm also stops flow. Table 4 defines which alarms also stop drug flow completely

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: patient-requested bolus. A patient-requested bolus shall be delivered at its prescribed rate Fbolus in addition to the prescribed basal flow rate Fbasal but no more than the maximim flow rate for the pump Fmax

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: max dose warning. Clinician commanded bolus shall be halted when continuinh to infuse prescribed VTBI will exceed hard limits retrieved from the drug library for the volume of drug infused over a period of time. Pump rate shall be reduced to KVO and a max dose warning be issued

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: halt pumping. The mechanical pump shall halt pumping when commanded or caused in response to an alarm condition (at end of pump stoke?)

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: device parameters. The PCA pump shall use a physician's prescriptions as device parameters

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: start infusion. Upon the clinician's pressing of the start button prescribed infusion shall commence

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: stop infusion. Upon the clinician's pressing of the stop button prescribed infusion shall halt

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: prescription confirmation. Required when changing prescription during infusion

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: soft limit confirmation. Prescriptions that violate the soft limits of the drug in the drug library shall issue a visible and audible warning requiring a soft limit confirmation by the clinician

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: hard limit. Prescriptions that violate a hard limit of the drug in the drug library shall be rejected with visible and audible indication when con rmation is attempted by the clinician

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: prescription retention. The patient's prescription shall be retained for at least ?data= 96 hours after the PCA pump is turned-off and unplugged

column1: Operation Subsystem: Operation Thread The operation thread performs primary pump operation control
column2: prescription confirmation. An authorized clinician must personally confirm the prescription is authentic and meant for the patient to be infused. column1: Operational Subsystem: Event Logger Thread The event logger thread records all actions or events for later review or audit
column2: event log. The PCA pump shall maintain an electronic event log to record each action taken by the pump and each event sensed of its environment

column1: Operational Subsystem: Event Logger Thread The event logger thread records all actions or events for later review or audit
column2: time stamp. Each log entry shall have a time stamp with its time of occurrence

column1: Operational Subsystem: Event Logger Thread The event logger thread records all actions or events for later review or audit
column2: log retention. Information in event and Fault Logs shall be retained for at least ?log= 1000 hours after the PCA pump is turned-off and unplugged

column1: Power Subsystem: Battery Provides reserve energy to operate the PCA Pump when mains power fails
column2: battery backup. The PCA pump shall continue to infuse for 10 minutes during interruption of mains electricity supply using battery backup either continuously or spread over an hour. (Five minutes to recharge per minute using battery.)

column1: Power Subsystem:Power Control Switches between battery-backup and mains supply  and detects anomalies like voltage out-of-range
column2: power and battery failure. Because with either working battery or power supply can operate the pump if the battery failure alarm and either the voltage out-o-range or the power supply failure alarms the the pump rate will be off otherwise the pump rate will continue at its previous value

column1: Power Subsystem:Power Control Switches between battery-backup and mains supply  and detects anomalies like voltage out-of-range
column2: remaining battery minutes. The user interface must show that the PCA pump is working on battery backup and an estimate of the number of minutes of battery-powered infusion remain

column1: Power Subsystem:Power Control Switches between battery-backup and mains supply  and detects anomalies like voltage out-of-range
column2: remaining battery accuracy. The estimate of remaining battery energy must be accurate to within Xbtty = 25%

column1: Power Subsystem:Power Control Switches between battery-backup and mains supply  and detects anomalies like voltage out-of-range
column2: low-battery warning. If the estimated battery life remaining is less than ?lba = 3 minutes the pump shall issue a low-battery warning

column1: Power Subsystem:Power Control Switches between battery-backup and mains supply  and detects anomalies like voltage out-of-range
column2: battery failure alarm. The PCA pump shall detect battery failure and issue a battery failure alarm

column1: Safety Subsystem: Alarm Thread The alarm thread (within the alarm process) evaluates fault signals to determine whether the infusion rate should be changed  issues alarm and warning signals to be sounded and displayed by the control panel  and creates fault entries to be stored in the fault log
column2: "issue alarms and warnings. The PCA pump shall issue alarms and warnings that require clinician attention

column1: Safety Subsystem: Alarm Thread The alarm thread (within the alarm process) evaluates fault signals to determine whether the infusion rate should be changed  issues alarm and warning signals to be sounded and displayed by the control panel  and creates fault entries to be stored in the fault log
column2: basal over-infusion alarm. IF delivered basal flow rate exceeds the prescribed basal rate setting by more than its allowered tolerance over a period of more than 5 minutes or immediately if the pump goes into free flow the pump shall issue a basal-overinfusion alarm. (EC3.2.7)

column1: Safety Subsystem: Alarm Thread The alarm thread (within the alarm process) evaluates fault signals to determine whether the infusion rate should be changed  issues alarm and warning signals to be sounded and displayed by the control panel  and creates fault entries to be stored in the fault log
column2: basal under-infusion warning. If delivered basal flow rate is less than the prescribed basal rate setting by more than its allowed tolerance over a period of more than 5 minutes or immediately if the flow stops the pump shall issue a basal under-infusion warning. (EC3.2.8)

column1: Safety Subsystem: Alarm Thread The alarm thread (within the alarm process) evaluates fault signals to determine whether the infusion rate should be changed  issues alarm and warning signals to be sounded and displayed by the control panel  and creates fault entries to be stored in the fault log
column2: bolus over-infusion alarm. If delivered patient-requested bolus flow rate exceeds the prescribed patient-requested bolus rate setting by more than its allowed tolerance over a period of more than 1 minute or immediately if the pump goes into free flow the pump shall issue a bolus over-infusion alarm. (EC 3.2.7)

column1: Safety Subsystem: Alarm Thread The alarm thread (within the alarm process) evaluates fault signals to determine whether the infusion rate should be changed  issues alarm and warning signals to be sounded and displayed by the control panel  and creates fault entries to be stored in the fault log
column2: bolus under-infusion warning. If patient-requested bolus is less than the prescribed bolus rate setting by more than its allowed tolerance over a period of more than 1 minute or immediately if the flow stops the pump shall issue a bolus under-infusion warning. (EC3.2.8)

column1: Safety Subsystem: Alarm Thread The alarm thread (within the alarm process) evaluates fault signals to determine whether the infusion rate should be changed  issues alarm and warning signals to be sounded and displayed by the control panel  and creates fault entries to be stored in the fault log
column2: square bolus over-infusion alarm. If delivered clinician-requested bolus flow rate exceeds the calculated square bolus rate by more than its allowed tolerance over a period of more than 5 minutes or immediately if the pump goes into free flow the pump shall issue a square bolus over-infusion alarm. (EC3.2.7)

column2: Channel Boundary (CB) Engineering ModeThe purpose of Channel Boundary Mode is to derive the optimum channel boundary settings from a flat field. Detector events produced in the M,N detector mode are collected and histogrammed for a commanded integration time.  The pseudo Instrument Y is transmitted to the ground.  Channel boundaries are derived from the Instrument Y and transmitted to the ICU and the ground.  Channel boundaries are sent by the ICU to the BPE and used in the detector event centroiding process.

column1: Functional Safety Architecture The functional safety architecture separates operation from error/fault detection  with a few exceptions. This allows safety requirements to be more easily achieved and verified. Components comprising the functional safety architecture are: Upstream Monitor Downstream Monitor Pump Fault Manager Alarm Thread  Error Detector Fault Logger  Failure LED  Power Control
column2: Built-In TestThere are two stages of Built-In Tests (BIT) for the DPU.  The Stage 1 BIT is included in the Bootstrap program and consists of Central Processing Unit (CPU) BIT, and Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) BIT.  The Stage 2 BIT is executed after the operating system is booted and is not part of the Bootstrap program.

column1: At startup, the DPU-RTOS shall execute the BIT device RAM tests (cold boot only), install device drivers, execute the BIT driver loopback tests (cold boot only), and then spawn the application flight software.
column2: Public FunctionsSets the poll rate and buffer rate to the given values.  If the values are out of range, the prior values are retained and an error is reported.  The scuiTask() semaphore timeout (scuiTaskTimeout) is automatically adjusted based on the given poll rate, by setting the timeout to approximately  the poll rate (not that the timeout is expressed in clock ticks, and so the resolution is low and only approximates  of the poll rate).

column1: Libwarc shall be memory safe and manage dynamic memory internally
column2: Control and Monitoringthe CCM Control Task initializes the DPU FSW. It is the responsibility of the CCM Control Task to establish a successful boot.  It does so by blocking on temporary semaphores, each with a 5 second timeout, after spawning the SCU Interface Task and the CCM Command Task.  If both of these tasks report a successful initialization by giving the semaphore, the CCM Control Task toggles the BC_INDEX parameter in EEPROM to indicate a successful boot.  If either task does not report a successful initialization, the CCM Control Task disables the watchdog strobe to effect a reboot of the DPU.  The rationale for selecting the successful initialization of these two tasks as the definition of a successful boot is that the DPU FSW requires these tasks, as a minimum, to establish ground contact and provide commandability.Once this initialization is complete, the task blocks on a binary semaphore which is given by the SCUI Command ISR upon arrival of the 1 Hz Clock Message.  In the event a Clock Message does not arrive, the semaphore will time out after 1.5 seconds.  The CCM Control Task remains alive to create and transmit DPU housekeeping at the appropriate intervals, perform various periodic processing tasks, and to process memory dump commands.The final call to ccmErrEnq() is performed in order that if an error occurs in an interrupt service routine, a global variable is set to the value of the errno which is then enqueued into the Error/Event Queue as part of this tasks normal processing.

column1: The DPU-SSI shall provide the capability for an application program to install a callback routine to respond to the receive IBG Interrupt.
column2: Event ProcessingThe Event Processor Task, after receiving a Mode command from the ICU, configures the DPU DCI hardware, responds to the ICU with a Mode Ready message then receives detector events by calling functions tmaliWait() and tmaliNextEvent().  The Event Processor Task will collect detector events for the time period specified in the Mode command then issue a Mode Complete message to the ICU.  After issuing the Mode Complete message, the Event Processor Task will enter the Idle state.

column2: Initialization The task invokes the initialization function scuiInit() which sets an instance variable, allocates ring buffers and semaphores for the Low and High Priority Telemetry Queues, initializes a buffer and semaphore for pending RT-RT command messages, creates the scuiTask() wakeup semaphore, initializes internal data structures, opens and initializes file descriptors for each of the required MIL-STD-1553 subaddresses and installs ISRs.  When the CCM CSC spawns the scuiTask(), it will block on a semaphore (ccmSemScuiSpawn) awaiting SCUI initialization.  Once initialization is complete, the SCUI CSC will signal successful initialization by giving the semaphore, and then write an empty STPDU to the 1553 shared memory.

column2: Telemetry Output to the Spacecraft 1553 BusThe SCU, which is a MIL-STD-1553 Bus Controller (BC), periodically reads the STPDU contained in the fifteen telemetry subaddresses, and then writes to the telemetry done subaddress.  When the telemetry done subaddress is written, the scuiTlmDoneISR() is called which gives a semaphore to awaken the scuiTask().  The software provides fault tolerance by automatically awaking after approximately two polling periods.  This timeout is automatically adjusted any time the SCU Poll Rate value is changed by command.

column2: Hardware InterfacesThe DPU-BOOTSTRAP must interface directly with the EEPROM on the Company X Communication Module.  The DPU-BOOTSTRAP accesses EEPROM as ?-bit words only.  The specific timing requirements of the EEPROM are satisfied in one of three ways:* the timing requirements are met by inserting specific wait loops (typical),* the timing requirements are met by use of the EEPROM Driver (DOWNLOAD command), andthe timing requirements are met implicitly by the amount of time which will be required to execute the intervening instructions regardless of the CPU speed setting (DRAM test logic).

column2: Receiving Commands from the ICUThe interface to the ICU is via a synchronous serial interface (SSI) bus, which utilizes an inter-block gap (IBG) to delineate complete messages from one another.  The DPU hardware produces an interrupt when it detects an IBG, and the SSI Driver provides a mechanism by which an application can install an interrupt hook routine to respond to an IBG interrupt.  Upon initialization, the ICUI CSC installs a hook routine into the SSI Driver called icuiCommandReceiveISR(), which verifies the checksum of an incoming command, transmits an ACK/NAK message to the ICU, and then enqueues the command for later processing by calling ccmCmdEnq().

Unless a fatal error is detected during initialization this task will never terminate.The specified 3 parameters specify the size of the TMALI queue and the initial parameters for the DCI, if the specified values are outside the allowed range default values will be used.The specified QueueSize is the allocated buffersize (in 4 byte EVENTS), the ring buffer is full when QueueSize-1 EVENTS are stored in the buffer.

column1: The DPU-DCI shall report errors to an application program by setting the ERRNO task variable and returning ERROR.
column2: CPU BITThe CPU BIT consists of a series of tests designed to test each of the functional units of the processor.  These include test for the Branch-Unit, the Fixed-Point Unit, the Floating-Point Unit, the Interrupt-Unit, and the Timer Unit.   Each of these tests consists of executing a few selected instructions from the this functional unit. The General Purpose Registers (GPR), the Segment Registers (SR), the Counter Register (CTR), and the Condition Register are tested for stuck-bits as part of the Branch-Unit test.  This is done by writing a 1s pattern (verified by reading it back) and then writing a 0s pattern (verified by reading it back).
